This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hello everybody, my name is Tomasz Bukowski, I will say a few words about myself in the next slide.
The title of my presentation is OMG WTF CTF, and I would like to persuade you to participate in CTFs
as a great value, a great source of everything. Who am I?
Well, probably a few persons here knows me. I was working in 3rd Polska for long, I gained a lot of experience, I'm very thankful for that experience.
I did learn stuff that probably I wouldn't be able to learn in other places.
Now I'm working in a big commercial company, Bank Millennium, that's why I need to wear a tie and a shirt when I'm going to the board.
But it is still fun, definitely those guys know how to have fun at work.
If I have a spare time, and my spare time is like a tiny slot for the whole week, I'm playing CTF with Dragon Sector.
Lately I don't have much time, but still I do that.
What I'm capable of doing? I do a bit of reverse engineering, sometimes I commit a code, basic exploitation, seriously basic,
like overflow a buffer and crash the software is fair enough for me.
Playing with web applications is web application security, in general IT security, including IT security policies,
and this boring and soft stuff regarding security.
And I'm a physicist, so basically I didn't learn everything that I mentioned before on studies,
I learned that in my last 7-8 years of working experience.
I know how to build a nuclear plant, if you are interested in building a nuclear plant, I can help you.
So the good, the bad and the ugly.
I thought that I need to somehow talk about the subject of this conference.
So basically something called Blue Team is not worth explanation, because everybody knows what Blue Team does.
Blue Team was always present in the IT security world, they were defending.
We were doing everything to not allow to compromise the infrastructure, to defend the infrastructure, etc.
And luckily, last few years showed that there is a need to formally create something called Red Team,
and the Red Teaming initiative in companies is still quite new, but it is good.
And I was very happy and very enthusiastic when I heard that there is even one step,
that we can do even one step ahead and make something that gives added value,
which is called Purple Teaming, Pink Teaming.
Basically, it is based on the knowledge, experience, exchange between those teams.
So making those teams work together gives the better value, better experience, better derivables than working separately.
Because if someone on this audience did try Red Teaming or like offensive security,
he knows that Red Team, the offensive player, will always find a blind spot, will always find a weakness,
and will always prove his state, like, I am able to exploit you because blah, blah, blah.
And in this approach, Blue Team is quite powerless, because the only thing they can do is defend,
and they are not able to see the whole scope from the point of view of attacker.
Okay, what the fuck is CTF?
Basically, CTF, we are not talking about Quake 3 Arena and those games.
CTF is a team competition related to IT security.
The basic principle is to solve a challenge.
One or more, sometimes more means many, many more.
Like old times, hack me, crack me, etc.
This is basically similar to what we can see in CTF competitions.
It can last for a few hours, like eight hours, I think is the shortest.
And the longest few days, ICTF was one or two weeks.
So, there is no general principle how long it can take.
And very, very often, CTF are the part of the IT conference.
Most common is IT security conference.
My team will lead the Dragon Sector CTF in the confidence conference in Krakow.
What task types can we see on the CTFs?
For example, the first, most common category is reversing.
Basically, we are getting a binary, we need to reverse it, understand the logic,
and get the flag.
Because the target of each task is to get the flag.
The flag is, in the most common situation, a string that is saying,
OK, congratulations, you found this secret that you need to look for.
So, in the reversing, you need to understand the logic of the binary
or somehow compiled, Python compiled, Java compiled file.
And get the flag, find it.
Or understand how to persuade the software to print you the flag
by understanding the logic.
The second is exploitation.
It is a bit related to reversing,
but you need to exploit the vulnerability in a software.
Very, very often, it is binary exploitation,
so you need to create a shellcode.
Sometimes, you need to exploit even on the kernel level.
So, you definitely need to be a low-level understanding guy to do that.
I have a hard time understanding that.
Cryptography.
This category consists of everything that is related to cryptography,
applied cryptography, and mistakes done by people implementing that.
Web applications.
I think that I don't need to explain that.
XSS, SQL injection, everything that we came up with regarding web applications.
There's a forensic.
For example, you are getting the image of a hard drive.
You need to find a flag or some secret there.
You are getting a pickup, so the recording of the network traffic.
Steganography.
Most hated category ever.
Basically, anyone here knows what steganography is?
Still sleeping.
Come on, come on.
Okay, so at least a few people know.
Basically, steganography is hiding a message in some other transmission,
like flipping the less significant bit in a bitmap.
So, you cannot see the difference in the bitmap because it is only one bit.
And you can use one pixel to transfer three bits of data.
And, for example, this way you can hide your data in the image.
Why is steganography the worst and the most hated?
Because there is no...
You can always hide something in something.
And very often you need to just dedicate what the author did try to do.
So, the category name should be guessing, not steganography.
The network, and by the network I mean how I made your packets.
Networking by crafting UDP, TCP packets,
and playing with the fancy properties of network protocols,
like tricking the network devices by TCP fragmentation, this level.
And one of the last, PPC, Power Programming,
a category for people with a lot of experience on coding.
Basically, in this category you need to write a code that is doing something,
which is not standard.

Like very weird type of maze solving.

some piece of hardware that is lying physically on the table.

CTF types, the first and the most common is Jello Party.

you choose the task, okay, I want to try to solve web application 100,
and you are getting a task description, please.
This is my vulnerable web application, please find the bug.
Very simple, very often the task scoring depends on how many people solve the task.
So, this way the weight of the task can be adjusted.
If it is too easy and too many people are solving, the task scoring is decreased.
And the best, my favorite type is attack-defense.
Fancy music goes here.
This is the visualization of DEF CON CTF.
Basically, in the attack-defense CTF, as the name goes,
you need to attack and defend the infrastructure.
So, in every case I know, you as a CTF team is receiving a set of services,
you need to protect them from being exploited,
and in the same time you need to exploit the same set of services
that is protected by other teams.
So, basically on this visualization we see the teams that managed to get to the DEF CON CTF finals,
and those fancy bullets, or I don't know, falling stars,
is the visualization of a successful attempt of exploit services of other teams.

Definitely recommended if you are even curious how to start solving stuff
